description: Covers how arrays are stored, indexed, and manipulated in memory. Core foundation for all DSA topics.

resources.title: Striver - Two Pointer & Sliding Window (pattern intro)

description: Two pointers allow solving array problems efficiently by moving pointers from start/end. Used heavily in interviews.

resources.title: NeetCode - Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters (sliding window example)

description: Sliding window optimizes subarray and substring problems by maintaining a dynamic window of elements.

resources.title: Striver - Prefix Sum / Product of Array Except Self (concept video)
NeetCode - Product of Array Except Self (walkthrough)

description: Prefix and suffix arrays help solve range queries and optimization problems efficiently using cumulative sums.
Searching includes linear and binary search. Binary search solves many interview questions efficiently.
Sorting organizes data for efficient processing. Includes quicksort, mergesort, selection sort and more.
Hashing helps solve frequency, distinct elements, and lookup problems in O(1) average time.
Subarray problems include sums, longest length, distinct elements, and optimization techniques.
2D arrays represent matrix-style data and include problems like rotation, search, and spiral traversal.
Greedy techniques combined with arrays solve interval, scheduling, and optimization problems efficiently.

resources.title: Striver - Trapping Rain Water (concept & monotonic stacks)

description: Includes medium to hard array interview patterns such as rainwater trapping, majority element, and rearrangements.
Introduces nodes, pointers, and the structure of linked lists with common operations such as traversal and creation.

resources.title: Striver - Insert & Delete in Linked List

description: Covers insertion, deletion, traversal and updating operations in a singly linked list.
Doubly linked lists allow forward and backward traversal with previous and next pointers.
Circular linked lists connect the last node back to the head to form a looped structure.
A fundamental linked list operation solved through pointer reversal or recursion.

resources.title: Striver - Detect Loop in Linked List (Tortoise & Hare)
GFG - Detect Loop in Linked List

description: Detects cycles in a linked list using fast and slow pointer method with O(1) space.

resources.title: GFG - Find Middle of Linked List

description: Uses the slow-fast pointer technique to find the middle node in one pass.

resources.title: Striver - Merge Two Sorted Linked Lists
GFG - Merge Two Sorted Linked Lists

description: Combines two sorted linked lists into one by sequential comparison of nodes.

resources.title: Striver - Remove Nth Node from End

description: Uses two pointers to remove a node in a single traversal from the end of the list.

description: Finds the common intersection node of two linked lists using length matching logic.
Rotates the list by k nodes by connecting tail to head and breaking at new head position.

topic: Flatten Linked List / Advanced LL Patterns
description: Solves multi-level linked list flattening using recursion and pointer rearrangement.
Covers stack fundamentals including push, pop, peek, and LIFO ordering  essential for many DSA problems.
Uses a stack to check if parentheses, braces and brackets are balanced in expressions.
Monotonic stack technique to find the next larger element for each array element efficiently.
Designs a stack that supports push, pop, top and retrieving minimum element in constant time.
Shows how to simulate stack operations (push/pop) using one or two queue data structures.
A classic 'hard' problem using monotonic stacks to compute maximum rectangular area in histograms.

resources.title: Striver - Introduction to Stack & Queue (Queue basics included)

description: Covers queue fundamentals including enqueue, dequeue, front, rear, and FIFO ordering.
Implements queue using circular indexing to optimize space and remove shifting issues.

resources.title: Striver - Queue Using Stacks (Two Stack Method)

description: Simulates FIFO behavior using two LIFO stacks for push and pop operations.
Simulates LIFO behavior using enqueue/dequeue operations of one or two queues.
Priority queues use heaps to process elements based on priority rather than FIFO order.

resources.title: NeetCode - Binary Tree Level Order Traversal

description: Queues play a major role in BFS traversal, level order traversal and other graph/tree-based problems.

Shows how recursive calls expand like a tree and helps in visualizing overall complexity.
Applies recursion to arrays for searching, printing, and subset generation.
Builds solutions step by step and backtracks whenever a choice leads to an invalid path.
Generates all possible subsets using recursive include/exclude branching.
Generates all permutations of an array or string using recursion and backtracking.
Recursively finds all number combinations that sum to a given target using include/exclude exploration.
String recursion helps solve problems such as reversal, palindrome checks, subsequences, and pattern creation.
A backtracking classic where queens must be placed such that no two attack each other.
A grid-based backtracking challenge where numbers are placed respecting Sudoku constraints.
A common recursion and backtracking problem involving navigating possible paths in a grid.
Shows how recursion with overlapping subproblems evolves into memoized dynamic programming solutions.
Backtracking explores decisions step-by-step and undoes them when a path becomes invalid. Useful for permutations, recursion trees and constraint problems.
Generates all subsets using include/exclude branching, forming the foundation for many backtracking problems.
Ensures only unique subsets are generated by sorting and skipping duplicate values.
Generates all permutations by swapping or building sequences recursively.
Generates unique permutations when duplicates are present by tracking visited or skipping repeated values.
Finds combinations that reach a target sum using recursive exploration and reuse of elements.
Generates all unique combinations where each number may be used only once.
Places N queens on a chessboard while ensuring no two queens attack each other using constraints and recursion.
Solves Sudoku puzzles by trying digits 19 in each cell while ensuring constraints are satisfied.
A classic grid-based search problem exploring all possible paths from start to destination via recursion.
Searches a 2D grid for a word by recursively exploring adjacent characters with backtracking.

description: Builds all possible character combinations formed from digits using DFS/backtracking.
